title: 112_hr1032
content: The Act may be cited as the "Removing Excess Litigation Involving Energy on Federal Lands Act" or the "RELIEF Act". Congress finds that the United States spends over $1 billion per day importing crude oil, representing the largest wealth transfer in history. The US has significant oil and natural gas reserves in the outer Continental Shelf, but legal challenges by environmental groups delay or prevent access to these resources, costing the American public and economy. Congress finds that expedited judicial review is necessary to prevent the abuse of the United States judicial system. All causes and claims from a covered energy project must be filed within 60 days of the Federal official's action. Failure to do so will result in the claim being barred. SEC. 4. DISTRICT COURT DEADLINE requires all proceedings under section 3 to be resolved within 180 days, taking precedence over other matters. Failure to meet the deadline results in dismissal with prejudice. SEC. 5. ABILITY TO SEEK APPELLATE REVIEW limits review to the Supreme Court. SEC. 6. DEADLINE FOR APPEAL TO THE SUPREME COURT is specified. SEC. 6. DEADLINE FOR APPEAL TO THE SUPREME COURT states that if the Supreme Court grants a writ of certiorari, the district court's judgment must be resolved within 180 days and takes precedence over other matters before the Supreme Court. SEC. 7. LIMITATION ON SCOPE OF REVIEW AND RELIEF. Judicial review of Federal actions under this Act presumes administrative findings correct unless proven otherwise by clear evidence. Prospective relief can only be granted if narrowly drawn and least intrusive means to correct violations. SEC. 8. LEGAL FEES. SEC. 8. LEGAL FEES. Any person filing a petition for judicial review under this Act must pay prevailing parties' fees unless their position was justified or special circumstances exist. SEC. 9. EXCLUSION. This Act does not apply to disputes between lease parties. SEC. 10. COVERED ENERGY PROJECT DEFINED. SEC. 10. COVERED ENERGY PROJECT DEFINED. A covered energy project refers to any Federal official's action or decision regarding leasing Federal lands for energy exploration, development, production, processing, or transmission, including actions under such a lease.
